definitions: held captive in a jail or prison as punishment for a crime
confined or restricted in movement or freedom like being trapped somewhere
examples: The imprisoned criminal served ten years for theft
Several imprisoned protesters went on a hunger strike
She felt imprisoned by her strict parents' rules
The miners were imprisoned underground after the cave-in

definitions: unlikely to occur or exist based on available evidence or circumstances
difficult to believe because it seems unrealistic or far-fetched
examples: An improbable victory surprised everyone watching the game
It's improbable that we'll finish before midnight
His improbable story about aliens made everyone laugh
The detective found the witness's alibi highly improbable

definitions: performed or done without previous preparation, planning, or rehearsal
arising naturally from immediate circumstances rather than being planned beforehand
examples: She gave an impromptu speech at the wedding
The musicians held an impromptu concert in the park
Their impromptu decision to travel changed everything
An impromptu meeting was called to discuss the crisis

definitions: not suitable or appropriate for the circumstances, purpose, or occasion
not in accordance with accepted rules, standards, or procedures
examples: His improper behavior at dinner shocked the guests
Wearing jeans to the interview was considered improper
The machine failed due to improper installation procedures
Improper use of the equipment caused serious damage

definitions: getting better in quality, condition, or performance over time
actively working to enhance or upgrade something's quality or effectiveness
examples: Her improving health made the family very happy
The improving economy led to more job opportunities
They spent weekends improving their old house together
The teacher focused on improving students' writing skills

definitions: created, performed, or done spontaneously without previous planning or practice
constructed or arranged from whatever materials or resources are immediately available
examples: The comedian's improvised jokes had everyone laughing
They performed an improvised scene based on suggestions
We built an improvised shelter using branches and leaves
The doctor used improvised tools during the emergency

definitions: acting or done quickly without thinking carefully about the consequences
characterized by or resulting from sudden strong emotions or desires
examples: Her impulsive decision to quit surprised her boss
Impulsive shoppers often regret their purchases later
His impulsive nature made him unpredictable and exciting
The impulsive child grabbed candy without asking first

definitions: containing unwanted substances or elements mixed with the original material
not morally clean or virtuous according to religious or ethical standards
examples: The impure water needed filtering before drinking
Impure metals must be refined before industrial use
Medieval texts often warned against impure thoughts
The priest spoke about avoiding impure intentions

definitions: impossible or very difficult to reach, enter, or get to physically
hard to understand or appreciate due to complexity or obscurity
examples: The mountain village remained inaccessible during winter storms
Important files were inaccessible after the system crashed
His inaccessible writing style frustrated many readers
The professor's lectures were inaccessible to beginners

definitions: not correct or precise in details, measurements, or facts
containing mistakes or false information that makes something unreliable
examples: The inaccurate map led them miles off course
His inaccurate predictions damaged his credibility
The report contained several inaccurate statistics
Inaccurate measurements ruined the entire construction project

definitions: not engaging in physical movement, exercise, or energetic activity
not currently functioning, working, or being used for its purpose
examples: The inactive lifestyle led to health problems
Bears become inactive during their winter hibernation
Her social media account has been inactive for months
The inactive volcano hadn't erupted for centuries

definitions: insufficient in quantity, size, or extent for a particular purpose
lacking the quality or capability needed to meet requirements
examples: The inadequate food supply caused widespread hunger
Their inadequate preparation showed during the presentation
His inadequate skills made the job impossible
The inadequate explanation left everyone confused

definitions: not allowed to be presented as evidence in a court of law
not able to be accepted or allowed in a particular situation
examples: The judge ruled the confession was inadmissible evidence
Hearsay testimony is often inadmissible in court
Late applications were deemed inadmissible by the committee
Such behavior is inadmissible in a professional setting

definitions: not resulting from or achieved through deliberate planning or intention
happening as a result of carelessness or lack of attention
examples: His inadvertent comment revealed the surprise party plans
The inadvertent error in calculation cost them money
She made an inadvertent mistake while typing quickly
The inadvertent disclosure of information caused problems

definitions: unable to be taken away from or given away by the possessor
belonging to someone permanently as an absolute right that cannot be removed
examples: The constitution protects certain inalienable rights of citizens
Freedom of speech is considered an inalienable right
Every human has inalienable dignity regardless of circumstances
The declaration spoke of inalienable liberties for all

definitions: not alive, especially not in the manner of animals and humans
lacking consciousness, movement, or the appearance of life
examples: The robot looked human but was completely inanimate
Artists often paint inanimate objects like fruit bowls
The inanimate doll suddenly seemed to move
He lay so still he appeared almost inanimate

definitions: impossible to hear or not loud enough to be heard clearly
producing sound at such a low volume that it cannot be perceived
examples: Her voice became inaudible over the loud music
The inaudible whisper left everyone guessing
The recording had several inaudible sections
His mumbling made his words almost inaudible

definitions: marking the beginning of an institution, activity, or period of office
being the first in a sequence of similar events or occasions
examples: The president's inaugural speech inspired the nation
They attended the inaugural ceremony at the museum
The inaugural flight of the new airline went smoothly
This is our inaugural issue of the magazine

definitions: suggesting that future success or good fortune is unlikely
not conducive to success or favorable outcomes
examples: Dark clouds made an inauspicious start to the wedding
The project began under inauspicious circumstances
An inauspicious economic forecast worried investors
Their inauspicious first meeting led nowhere

definitions: not genuine, sincere, or true to one's real nature or beliefs
made to appear genuine but actually false or copied
examples: His inauthentic smile didn't fool anyone
The inauthentic apology only made things worse
Experts identified the painting as an inauthentic copy
The inauthentic designer bag was obviously fake

definitions: located or positioned within the hull or toward the center of a ship or boat
situated nearer to the center or inside of something, especially a vehicle
examples: The inboard motor was protected from rough waters
Passengers moved to inboard seats during the storm
The inboard wheels need different maintenance procedures
Keep heavy cargo in an inboard position

definitions: existing in a person or animal from birth rather than acquired or learned
forming part of the natural character or basic nature of someone
examples: Her inborn talent for music showed very early
Some people have an inborn fear of heights
His inborn curiosity led him to become a scientist
The baby's inborn reflexes were tested by doctors

definitions: traveling toward a particular place, especially when returning to the starting point
directed or moving toward the inside or center of something
examples: All inbound flights were delayed by the storm
The inbound train arrives at platform three
Monitor all inbound calls to customer service
Inbound traffic was heavy during rush hour

definitions: produced by breeding between closely related individuals within a species
existing as a basic or inherent feature that has been reinforced over time
examples: The inbred puppies had several health problems
Inbred populations often lack genetic diversity
Their inbred suspicion of outsiders was hard to overcome
Years of isolation created inbred cultural traditions

definitions: emitting light as a result of being heated to a high temperature
showing strong emotion, especially anger, or exceptional brilliance
examples: The incandescent bulb glowed warmly in the lamp
Incandescent metal in the forge glowed bright orange
She was incandescent with rage after the betrayal
His incandescent performance earned a standing ovation

definitions: unable to do or achieve something due to lack of ability, power, or resources
not having the necessary ability, qualification, or strength to perform a task
examples: He seemed incapable of telling the truth
The damaged ship was incapable of continuing
She felt incapable of handling such responsibility
The old computer was incapable of running new software

definitions: deprived of strength or ability to function normally, especially due to illness or injury
legally disqualified from acting due to physical or mental inability
examples: The accident left him temporarily incapacitated
Several incapacitated patients needed constant care
The incapacitated person required a legal guardian
She was legally incapacitated and couldn't sign contracts

definitions: causing someone to be unable to work or do things normally
severely limiting one's ability to perform usual activities or duties
examples: The incapacitating pain made it impossible to walk
An incapacitating illness kept her bedridden for weeks
The incapacitating fear of flying limited his travel
Incapacitating regulations hindered business growth

definitions: embodied in flesh or taking on physical, especially human, form
representing or being a perfect example of a particular quality
examples: Christians believe God became incarnate in Jesus
The deity was said to be incarnate in human form
He was evil incarnate in the eyes of victims
She seemed to be patience incarnate with children

definitions: designed to cause fires or containing chemicals that produce fire
tending to stir up conflict, violence, or strong emotions
examples: The incendiary bomb destroyed the entire building
Incendiary devices were found in the abandoned warehouse
His incendiary speech sparked violent protests
The article's incendiary language angered many readers

definitions: very angry, especially about something unfair or wrong
filled with rage or fury to an extreme degree
examples: She was incensed by the unfair treatment
The incensed crowd demanded justice
He became incensed when he discovered the betrayal
Parents were incensed about the school's decision

definitions: continuing without pause or interruption in an annoying way
occurring so frequently as to seem constant and unending
examples: The incessant rain ruined our camping trip
Her incessant talking gave everyone a headache
The baby's incessant crying kept them awake
Incessant phone calls disrupted the entire office

definitions: involving sexual relations between people too closely related to marry legally
involving relationships that are unhealthily close or exclusive
examples: The novel explored an incestuous relationship between siblings
Incestuous marriages were common in ancient royal families
The incestuous business relationships led to corruption
Critics described the industry as incestuous and insular

definitions: happening as a minor accompaniment to something more important
occurring by chance in connection with something else
examples: We had an incidental meeting at the store
Any resemblance to real persons is purely incidental
Don't worry about incidental expenses during the trip
The story included incidental details about her childhood

definitions: beginning to happen or develop but not fully formed
in an initial or early stage of development
examples: Doctors detected incipient signs of the disease
The incipient rebellion was quickly suppressed
An incipient romance bloomed between the coworkers
The incipient storm clouds gathered on the horizon

definitions: cut into a surface, especially with a sharp tool for decoration
marked or decorated with lines or figures cut into the surface
examples: The incised patterns on the vase were beautiful
Ancient incised stones marked the burial site
The surgeon made carefully incised lines
Incised wounds require different treatment than tears

definitions: intelligently analytical and clear in expression or thought
quick to understand and make sharp, direct judgments or decisions
examples: Her incisive analysis impressed the board members
The critic wrote an incisive review of the play
His incisive wit made him popular at parties
The lawyer's incisive questions revealed the truth

definitions: unpleasantly cold, wet, or stormy weather that makes outdoor activities difficult
showing no mercy or leniency in treatment or judgment
examples: The inclement weather forced us to cancel the picnic
Ships stayed in port during the inclement conditions
The judge showed an inclement attitude toward repeat offenders
His inclement response shocked everyone present

definitions: leaning or turning away from the vertical or horizontal
having a tendency, preference, or natural disposition toward something
examples: The inclined surface made walking difficult
We climbed the steeply inclined mountain path
She's inclined to believe his story
I'm inclined to agree with your assessment

definitions: contained as part of a whole or group
covered or incorporated within the scope of something
examples: Breakfast is included in the hotel room price
All students are included in the new program
Tax is not included in the displayed prices
Everyone felt included in the celebration

definitions: including all the services, facilities, or items normally expected or required
not excluding any section of society or any party involved
examples: The inclusive price covers meals and entertainment
We offer inclusive packages for family vacations
The school promotes an inclusive environment for all
Their inclusive policies welcomed diverse participants

definitions: having one's true identity concealed to avoid being recognized
in a disguised state to maintain anonymity or privacy
examples: The celebrity traveled incognito to avoid fans
She went incognito to the party wearing sunglasses
The prince lived incognito in the small town
Browsing incognito doesn't save your search history

definitions: expressed in a confusing way without logical connection of ideas
unable to speak intelligibly or think clearly
examples: His incoherent essay received a failing grade
The plot was incoherent and hard to follow
The patient became incoherent after the accident
She was incoherent with grief at the funeral

definitions: arriving at or approaching a place or position
recently elected or appointed but not yet in office
examples: Watch out for incoming traffic at this intersection
The receptionist handles all incoming calls
The incoming president will take office in January
Incoming students must attend orientation week

definitions: without an equal in quality or extent, matchless in excellence
unable to be compared because of being fundamentally different
examples: Her incomparable beauty stunned everyone present
The chef's incomparable skill earned international fame
The two situations are incomparable in nature
Their incomparable experiences made discussion difficult

definitions: unable to exist together in harmony due to fundamental differences
unsuitable for use together because of different properties or requirements
examples: Their incompatible personalities led to constant arguing
The two chemicals are incompatible and may explode
This software is incompatible with older computers
Our incompatible schedules made dating impossible

definitions: not having or showing the necessary skills to do something successfully
not legally qualified or capable of performing required duties
examples: The incompetent manager was finally fired
His incompetent handling of the crisis cost millions
The court declared her incompetent to stand trial
An incompetent lawyer can ruin your case

definitions: not having all the necessary or appropriate parts
not finished or brought to an end
examples: The incomplete puzzle frustrated the children
She submitted an incomplete application form
His incomplete work earned a failing grade
The building remains incomplete after two years

definitions: impossible to understand or grasp mentally due to complexity or obscurity
beyond the limits of understanding or normal comprehension
examples: The professor's explanation was completely incomprehensible
Ancient texts can be incomprehensible without translation
His incomprehensible behavior worried his family
The contract's incomprehensible language confused everyone

definitions: impossible to imagine, understand, or believe because it's so unlikely or strange
beyond the limits of what can be grasped by the mind
examples: It's inconceivable that he would betray us
The scale of the universe is almost inconceivable
Such cruelty was inconceivable to most people
An inconceivable amount of money was stolen
